name: fitr
body:
The `fitr` package is a tool for fitting reinforcement learning (RL) models to behavioural data. Currently, it's in _very_ early stages of development, and __only the Matlab package is presently functional__. There is not yet any documentation, but we're working on that.

Much credit is owed to Samuel Gershman for his [`mfit` package](https://github.com/sjgershm/mfit) from which I learned a great deal about implementing RL model fitting. Currently, the `fitr` Bayesian Model Selection code uses many of the functions from `mfit`, but an independent implementation is underway.

I am working on the python and Julia packages, but improving the quality of the Matlab version is currently my main priority. 

Future goals include:

* Documentation
* Built-in gradient computations for common models
* Bridging with tools such as SPM and VBA-Toolbox
* Expanding base of built-in tasks
* Improving speed by fitting subjects in parallel
* Exploring GPU-acceleration

### References

1. Huys, Q. J. M., Cools, R., Gölzer, M., Friedel, E., Heinz, A., Dolan, R. J., & Dayan, P. (2011). Disentangling the roles of approach, activation and valence in instrumental and pavlovian responding. PLoS Computational Biology, 7(4). http://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1002028
2. Gershman, S. J. (2016). Empirical priors for reinforcement learning models. Journal of Mathematical Psychology, 71, 1–6. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.jmp.2016.01.006
3. Rigoux, L., Stephan, K. E., Friston, K. J., & Daunizeau, J. (2014). Bayesian model selection for group studies - Revisited. NeuroImage, 84, 971–985. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2013.08.065
4. Daw, N. D. (2011). Trial-by-trial data analysis using computational models. Decision Making, Affect, and Learning: Attention and Performance XXIII, 1–26. http://doi.org/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199600434.003.0001
